headline.main: LeRoy Neiman Dined Here With Pen and Fork

docs.snippet: Maggie Talisman, the chef and an owner of Dishes at Home, which just moved into the Grand Central Market at 43rd Street and Lexington Avenue, does not have anyone's diet in mind when she whips up her silky, almost candylike Valrhona chocolate pudd...
docs.abstract: Comment on ready-to-cook items available at Dishes at Home, in Grand Central Market; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Maggie Talisman, the chef and an owner of Dishes at Home, which just moved into the Grand Central Market at 43rd Street and Lexington Avenue, does not have anyone's diet in mind when she whips up her silky, almost candylike Valrhona chocolate pudding ($4.25 a half-pound), or fries her torpedo-size Russian mushroom or meat-filled piroshki ($3.50 each).

headline.main: Meals to Go At Grand Central (Just Add Stove)

docs.snippet: What was your grandmother's favorite dessert recipe? Here's a chance to make Grandma almost famous, by having her dessert served in the cafe of the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art in Hartford this fall and winter. What you have to do is enter the...
docs.abstract: Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art, Hartford, Conn, is holding recipe contest in conjunction with exhibition of paintings by Grandma Moses; winners will have their grandmothers' desserts served in museum cafe; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: What was your grandmother's favorite dessert recipe? Here's a chance to make Grandma almost famous, by having her dessert served in the cafe of the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art in Hartford this fall and winter. What you have to do is enter the recipe in a contest that is being held in conjunction with the museum's exhibition of paintings by Grandma Moses, on view from Oct. 3 through Feb. 15. (Right, the artist's ''Old Times.'') The recipe does not have to be original, but an explanation of its source should be included.

headline.main: For Grandmas Whose Baking Is an Art Form

docs.snippet: The toma bella is the aptly named offspring of a tomato and a bell pepper. This hybrid, which originated in Japan, is now being grown in Mexico, California and Michigan and is sold with the Frieda's Finest label in supermarkets, including Food Tow...
docs.abstract: Toma bella is hybrid offspring of tomato and bell pepper and is sold with Frieda's Finest label in supermarkets; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: The toma bella is the aptly named offspring of a tomato and a bell pepper. This hybrid, which originated in Japan, is now being grown in Mexico, California and Michigan and is sold with the Frieda's Finest label in supermarkets, including Food Town in New Jersey. Bright red and squat like a tomato, it has a somewhat milder, sweeter flavor than a bell pepper. But inside it is just like a pepper, so once the seeds and core have been scooped out it's ideal to stuff and bake. It can also be baked empty until the flesh softens, about 20 minutes at 400 degrees, then filled and served cold. Or it can be used raw to hold dips and sauces. In markets, toma bellas, which will be available through September, are about $6 a pound; they are $65.55 for five pounds, including two-day shipping, from Frieda's, at www.friedas.com or (800) 241-1771.

headline.main: Mom's a Pepper, Dad's a Tomato: Baby Is a Sweetie, If a Tad Unlovely

docs.snippet: Jelli Bowls, 12-inch bowls in four vibrant colors, are molded from plastic cutting-board material, making them virtually indestructible and perfect for holding summer salads, chips or fruit, indoors or out. They are light enough to take on a picni...
docs.abstract: Jelli Bowls, 12-inch bowls in four vibrant colors, are molded from plastic cutting-board material, making them virtually indestructible and perfect for holding summer salads, chips or fruit; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Jelli Bowls, 12-inch bowls in four vibrant colors, are molded from plastic cutting-board material, making them virtually indestructible and perfect for holding summer salads, chips or fruit, indoors or out. They are light enough to take on a picnic, will even float in a pool and can go in the dishwasher. They come in red, lime, cobalt and orange, and are $11 each. Flower-shape salad servers are $7.50. All at the Art of Cooking, 555 Hudson Street (Perry Street).

headline.main: The Bowls of Summer, for Picnics in the Pool or Out

docs.snippet: With the dollar's slide, even having a couple of drinks at Bar Hemingway in the Ritz hotel in Paris is a splurge. So do the next best thing: mix yourself a drink at home and page through ''The Cocktails of the Ritz Paris'' by Colin Peter Field (Si...
docs.abstract: The Cocktails of the Ritz Paris is new book by Colin Peter Field, head bartender at hotel's Bar Hemingway; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: With the dollar's slide, even having a couple of drinks at Bar Hemingway in the Ritz hotel in Paris is a splurge. So do the next best thing: mix yourself a drink at home and page through ''The Cocktails of the Ritz Paris'' by Colin Peter Field (Simon & Schuster, $19.95). With the light sophistication of a Cole Porter song, Mr. Field, the head bartender at Bar Hemingway, gives cocktail history and lore with advice on concocting drinks. The book, linen-bound with charming illustrations by Yoko Ueta (including martini-swilling rabbits and kangaroos), is not an encyclopedia, but still might make a nice Father's Day gift. Mr. Field spends pages on the martini but does not tell how to make the classic version. The recipes are given in proportions, in tenths, not in spoons or ounces. He describes a New Age martini without alcohol, but that recipe is another mystery.

headline.main: For Fathers Who Prefer the Bar to the Grill

docs.snippet: Slow Food, which tries to preserve artisanal food, has issued ''The Slow Food Guide to New York City Restaurants, Markets and Bars,'' by Patrick Martins and Ben Watson (Chelsea Green, $20). It highlights places that use organic products and ingred...
docs.abstract: Slow Food, which tries to preserve artisanal food, issues The Slow Food Guide to New York City Restaurants, Markets and Bars; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Slow Food, which tries to preserve artisanal food, has issued ''The Slow Food Guide to New York City Restaurants, Markets and Bars,'' by Patrick Martins and Ben Watson (Chelsea Green, $20). It highlights places that use organic products and ingredients from local farms, and others that have been family-run for generations. It digs deep into neighborhoods all over and is excellent on ethnic shops and dining spots. Mr. Martins is the director of Slow Food U.S.A., and Mr. Watson works for the publisher. The contributors include food writers like Barbara Kafka, chefs like Mario Batali and a few publicists. The book will not be in stores until October, but it is now sold by Slow Food for $16 plus shipping; (212) 965-5640.

docs.snippet: Choosing hot dogs for your summer grilling season might take some time. A count of the varieties sold in a supermarket in my neighborhood exceeded 20. And this year there are a few more to consider.     Hobart Market, a butcher and smoker in the w...
docs.abstract: Interesting varieties of hot dogs are available from several sources; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Choosing hot dogs for your summer grilling season might take some time. A count of the varieties sold in a supermarket in my neighborhood exceeded 20. And this year there are a few more to consider. Hobart Market, a butcher and smoker in the western Catskills, makes meaty pork, beef and combination pork and beef hot dogs in natural casings, $9.99 for two pounds. Better still are its rich bratwurst, peppery andouille and garlickly kabanosy (a kind of skinny kielbasa), all $13 for two pounds from info@hobartmarket.com or (607) 538-9721. The market, in Hobart, N.Y., reopens for the season this weekend but mail orders are filled year-round. Fairway also carries the sausages.

headline.main: How Do I Love Thee, Hot Dog? Let Me Count the Ways

docs.snippet: M Boutique, tucked just inside the door of the new Morrells Restaurant, which opens tomorrow at 900 Broadway (20th Street), carries some items that you would expect from its wine-store owners, like sterling silver wine coasters ($99 each) and oliv...
docs.abstract: M Boutique in Manhattan sells Danish coffeemaker called CafeSolo; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: M Boutique, tucked just inside the door of the new Morrells Restaurant, which opens tomorrow at 900 Broadway (20th Street), carries some items that you would expect from its wine-store owners, like sterling silver wine coasters ($99 each) and olive oils made by wineries (Nikos Antonakeas, an owner, and Dagmar Venus, the retail manager, stock the shelves, above). Other items are surprising, like a Danish coffeemaker called CafeSolo, left. Ground coffee and boiling water are stirred in the carafe, allowed to sit for four minutes, then poured through a filter. It's a bit like cowboy chuck-wagon coffee (coffee and water boiled together), but the result has a rich extraction and less sediment than with a French press pot. The coffeemakers, which come with wet-suit-style jackets, are $69 for a four-cup pot, $64 for a two-cup.

docs.snippet: Clarified butter is clear golden fat: melted unsalted butter with its water and solids skimmed off. It's what you need for béarnaise or hollandaise sauce; it also does not scorch like regular butter, which is a boon when sautéing. Making it your...
docs.abstract: Plugra introduces clarified butter in jars; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Clarified butter is clear golden fat: melted unsalted butter with its water and solids skimmed off. It's what you need for béarnaise or hollandaise sauce; it also does not scorch like regular butter, which is a boon when sautéing. Making it yourself is time consuming, but it is sold in jars (sometimes labeled ghee). Now Plugrá, an American brand of higher-fat European-style butter, has its own, which is $10 for 12 ounces at Williams-Sonoma stores.

headline.main: Taking the Scorch Out of Butter
